author: ra226
title: Fun 'bot, lots of articulation, and a great parts selection
review:
The Spybot was a memorable little set from the Classic Space era and came in a two pack along with #1499, the Twin Starfire.  As far as I can tell, this set is unique among space sets in that it's the only one that doesn't include a minifig.  I'm not sure if it was ever sold outside the two pack, so perhaps it was intended to be played with one of the figs from the Starfire.  Parts selection includes a few tools, and tons of classic, first generation computer pieces.

This guy has great articulation, too, especially for such a small set: wrists, elbows, shoulders, head swivel, and the legs can bow outward to give him a sort of hover mode (I loved that feature as a kid).  The rocket pack on his back as well as thrusters behind the feet and head all lend themselves well to the hover mode.  I remember modifying mine to have a platform behind the head (swapping in a 2x3 for the 1x2 with bars) so a minifig could sit there and control him using the two antennae on his head as control sticks.

A great little set from back in the day.

author: JoystickJunkie
title: A big robot, with lots of articulation, parts and heart.
review:
I found this set for cheap on Gumtree here in Australia - well, comparatively cheap.  It cost me $20 bucks for this little guy in a Zip-Loc bag but apparently this was a North America exclusive set.  

The set comprises a robot, and that's it. No minifigures, or alternate builds.  You get a robot, but you get a really nice robot who looks kinda cute and fits in well with your spacemen on the moon.

Building Experience

The building experience is simply, working from the feet up to the head of the robot, with some small bits of sideways building for the arms.  There's nothing here that should puzzle or confuse you, but pay attention as you build as the old Lego Space instructions can sometimes be a little odd or condense multiple parts into a single step.  Otherwise, you're left with a tall, chunky robot with lots of articulation, with a rocket pack on its back and some tool slots.

Parts

You get some great pieces for your collection - three printed console tiles, two sloped computer screens with buttons and lots of small slopes, hinges, turntables, etc.  There are no special pieces exclusive to this set, so if you do a "Parts Out" on Bricklink, you can easily assemble this from a stock of cheap, easy to find pieces.  And due to many of the pieces being quite cheap and easy to find, you can easily get quite a few of these online by simply knowing which parts to buy.

Playability

This is a seriously cool little model.  The arms can bend up and out, the elbows can bend and the hands, which are done with little brackets, can turn on their stud connection to the wrist.  The legs, on the other hand (or other foot), don't have nearly as much articulation.  The legs instead fold up outwards to give the impression of a sort of hover or rocket mode. 

The robot is much larger than you think it is - easily towering over a minifigure.  In fact it's so much larger that it won't fit through doors, or inside enclosed bases, spaceships or rovers.  You'd have to imagine this to perhaps be a large robot build to endure the lunar surface?  Maybe it's a constructor robot, built for heaving lifting, scouting out the moons, and exploratory stuff.  A minifigure can interact with the computer panels, as if the robot is also a mobile processing thing perhaps?

The title of the set is “Spy-Bot” but I don't know how something so large is meant to be a “spy“.  Maybe it can hack into computer systems?  Maybe it's meant as a recon thing?  Not sure who it's mean to spy on as I don't think the whole conflict in space thing was established until Futuron v Blacktron v Spacepolice thing.

Value for Money

First off, ignore the "set" option on Bricklink as paying $49.95 USD for this set (Up to $80 Australian dollars) for this set is ridiculous.  Simply buy the parts and build it that way, there's no special or hard to find pieces in this set.  You can probably build this one for $15 to $30 bucks depending on the right Bricklink store.  That being said, I have never seen this set appear on eBay or anywhere else so chances of finding a full set seem kinda slim.

Secondly, I think this is a great little set. Seriously lovely, great articulation and I could see it having lots of adventures with a mobile space team on the moon, whether in conflict or exploration.
